One of the great retro FPSes, Shadow Warrior is somewhat similar in gameplay to Duke Nukem 3D. The game is definitely quite difficult, but the introduction of quicksaving and quickloading eases off the difficulty for newer players. Since much of the game's humor comes from he hilariously stereotypical protagonist Liu Wang, some players may find it racist, but it's all just in good fun. The game looks good for its time, and the sound assets are great.   Gameplay wise, the game plays great. The player can fight enemies with his fists, a katana, dual-weilding uzis, a rocket launcher with optional heat seeking missiles and even a nuke, a heart that creates a clone of Liu Wang, and more. The stage design is usually a major strength in old FPSes, and Shadow Warrior is no exception. The huge, expansive stages are fun to explore and packed with secrets. Enemy variation is not the best, but there's definitely enough to keep the player entertained.  The port remains faithful to the original, but one of the new editions is a multiplayer mode. It works well, but I rarely use it. One of the multiplayer's greatest strengths is the ability to design stages and share them with full Steam Workshop Support.  It may not be as well known as Duke Nukem 3D or Doom, but it's definitely just as good. From veterans to new players alike, Shadow Warrior Classic Redux is a classic that's definitely still worth the price today.

Shadow Warrior is another great, classic FPS from 3D Realms, the last before they went on to do Duke Nukem Forever. Compared to Duke Nukem 3D the level design has improved even more, all of them seem very well thought out. They make also more use of destructable wall than before, some for revealing secrets or to progress. The style is pretty much the same: find the end of the level, sometimes hindered by locked doors for which keys have to be found. The weapon fit the style of the game, but are not as unique as in DN3D. Beware that the game is very racist against asians and sexist. It spawned controvery at its release and is probably the reason why it didn't sell as well as DN3D did. Especially the comments of protagonist Lo Wang can be quiet bawdy, more than the 'modern' Lo Wang in the Shadow Warrior reboot of 2013 and even Duke Nukem. The Classic-Redux-Edition features improved music and graphics which look nice in Full-HD resolution but keeping the style of the original. If you prefer the low quality music and sound and heavily pixelated graphics of the original you can still play it as it is included. Also included are the two expansion packs Twin Dragon and Wanton Destruction. WD was made by Sunstorm Interactiv which also made solid expansion packs for DN3D and this one follows them. They have some good level design, although it does not reach the quality of the base game, but are still worth to play. Twin Dragon on the other hand features large, mostly boring and uninspired levels that are more like the ones in modern FPS than the labyrinths of the classics. Especially annoying are the hidden mines in some levels that kill you instantly - not a good fit to a fast paced FPS.  I'd recommend the game for everybody who enjoys old school FPS like Doom, Quake or DN3D, although I think Shadow Warrior doesn't reach their quality, but comes very close. The Classic Redux is probably the best version to enjoy the game today.

As far as actual contents go, this contains all the Shadow Warrior goodness that came out -- the base as well as both expansions. All optimized to run natively on modern machines, so no more DOSBox. Graphics got smoothed out and improved a bit, though they kindly left an option to stick to the classic textures. So yeah, runs fast and looks good -- all a classic fps fan needs!  Oh yeah, this package also includes the classic '97 version running through DOSBox. This is the same version that is available as a f2p title, and content-wise is an exact copy of the original Shadow Warrior compact disc from 16 years ago -- so 4 missions, and a full soundtrack. Expansion packs for the classic are freeware and can easily be added in.

Powerups: fortune cookies give health boost, armor, Nuclear bombs, Heatseeker cards for rocket launcher.  Interesting enemies like female warriors, Sumos, even ghosts.  There is less nudity than Duke3D, the girls are anime girls.  Keys can be used multiple times, you have the keyscards but you also have keys for locks.  The game is more fast-paced than Duke3D but at the same time easier. My main weapon in Duke3D was a shotgun, in Shadow Warrior its the dual Uzi.  Bosses are also easier, not giant alien monsters.

I started out really disliking Shadow Warrior. It felt like just Duke Nukem 3D Map Pack with a stupid character added in... boy was I wrong. I played the first 5 minutes groaning in regret of my purchase, then it hit me. Or I hit an enemy and the achievement counter started for 'More Personal Weapon'. I questioned this newfound discovery until I realized.. 'Wang prefer sword, more personal weapon' Then the anime girls with Uzis that made NO SENSE appeared and I was hooked. After having beat the first part of the game, it feels like opposites. Where Duke Nukem had easy to use weapons, but intricately designed levels, Shadow Warrior has relatively more simple levels but an intricate combat system. Each weapon has an alternate fire, to great effect, even giving you the ability to launch a nuke. Shruikens are speedy spreading projectiles, but the fact that you can recover them from walls makes their weakness actually usefull, since you'll almost always have ammo, a 4 barreled ♥♥♥♥ing shotgun, dual weild innaccurate weapons. The flow of combat deviates, although slightly, from Duke Nukem 3D, which makes, gameplay wise, a more independent game fun rather than living in the shadow of it's predecessor. Lu Wang suprised me with his humor. Once again, I started off disliking him, but once the one liners struck, I was hooked. If you're thinking about getting Shadow Warrior, but scared because it'd just be like Duke Nukem, I say buy it. It's different enough to stand alone, yet similar enough to give you the same rush.

'The definitive version of the cult classic shooter, Shadow Warrior Classic Redux features remastered visuals and two massive expansion packs. Corporations rule every facet of life in a near-future Japan and employ Shadow Warriors, one-man armies of unparalleled skill, to protect their power' - Shadow Warrior Classic Redux.   I've always been a fan of the old 90's shoot em up games. I remember Duke Nukem, Shadow Warrior and Doom 1+2 as fun and exciting games where level design and graphics blew my mind. Now we are so lucky to get remastered version on all of these game and yes I still enjoy them!   Shadow Warrior Classic Redux gives you a lot of content. 2 base episode + 2 expansion episodes. Each episode has around 10-20 levels. Each level is designed well and feels open with different paths. The maps are big and filled with secrets and easter eggs (which I love). Graphics looks good and it runs easily with 400 fps. The game itself launches without problems and doesn't crash at all. Widescreen support is also very handy! The gameplay is fun and exciting. It plays like Duke Nukem and Doom where you have to get to exit on each map. Find keys to unlock doors, solve puzzles and defeat many different enemies on your path with a big arsenal of guns (smgs, shotguns, rpg's, katana etc.). The game might be hard for someone unfamiliar with old school shooters, so don't rush it. You need all them health packs and armour pickups ;)  If you are a big fan of the old games and just wanna have a nostalgic feeling, buy this game! It's cheap and offers a lot of content. The game got humour, gore, run and gun, big maps, a vast of different enemies and guns, secrets and most important it offers a lot of fun!  Get hyped for Shadow Warrior 2! :D

Definetly a great old school shooter.  Pros: -Great arsenal of weapons compared to Duke Nukem. The Uzis are good for fast enemies and the missile launcher and grenade launcher can blow up enemies to pieces. -Maps are maze like with keycards to open the next area. It never gets confusing and I never had to look up a walkthrough to find out where to go. -FOV slider -Great environments from ancient Japan like levels to Japanese towns. -The graphics are appealing -When you blow up an enemy his body parts fly in the air. -Some weapons have an alternative fire. For example the riot gun can fire one shell or 6 shells consecutively. You can fire 2 Uzis or one. You can use regular missiles or heat sinking missiles (with a power up) or a nuke. This would be used in Half Life which came out the following year.  Cons -Sometimes your grenade launcher will make fire on the ground where you have to backtrack and you will occasionally take damage from touching it. -The default mouse controls are awful but can be fixed by changing the X-axis scale and Y-Axis scale. -Every single line out of Lo Wang is a joke referring to his giant wang. He gets annoying quickly. You basically play as an old bad ♥♥♥ pervert. Also he speaks in broken English. You can always turn off his voice though. -The story is not really that good. Yes this is a 90's game but it came out a year before Half Life.  This is the last game 3d Realms developed before Duke Nukem Forever. It is a great goodbye to the end of an era of old school shooters. If you liked Duke Nukem you might like this game. I say might because I think Duke is a more appealing character for some reason. Whatever the case, Shadow Warrior Classic Redux has great level design, great weapons with alternative fire, and plenty of secrets to find.

For less than one american dollar on sale, Shadow Warrior will offer you hours of intricate level design, challenging gameplay, and hilarious level design in what many would consider a lesser-known FPS shooter in the same vein of Doom, Wolfenstein, and Duke Nukem. Though it was overshadowed by its successors, its values surrounding diverse weapons, enemies, and dialogue are not to be understated. As is the nature of these older FPS, don't expect a great deal of variety in combat. The enemies can get challenging and the tasks repetitive, but the combat is mostly the same. Fans seeking a nostalgic FPS with some of the funniest one-liners in gaming history should pony up for a couple hours of fun.   If you're not convinced by the overwhelming amount of praise, you can check out the original 1997 version of the game for FREE.

In the end, I would recommend this game for modern gamers that can still enjoy DOOM style 'find the key, unlock the door' type of gameplay. The humor, art direction, and general badassery make it a very memorable experience.   Story time: In case you didn't know, Steam offers a DOSBox version of this game for free (The original 1997 version). I installed and played the first level of the original, but had to stop because of how poorly the graphics and menu/saving systems have aged over the years. I then discovered this remake and picked it up on a sale. This remake fixed every issue I had with the original DOS version, which is great because now I get to enjoy and old '97 classic in 2016.  Visually, the remake brings the old look of the original game up to modern HD standards. Think Half-Life or Quake style 3D environments with DOOM style 2D sprites. The run and gun action is pretty solid and the humor is pretty great (even if it's extremely racist). The story takes a back seat, but that's not really why anyone would play this game.  Also with this remake, you get access to the Twin Dragon and Wanton Destruction expansions (though you cannot access them in the base game's menu system which makes no sense to me). Overall, there's probably about 15-20 hours of gameplay in all of Classic Redux.  The biggest issue with the game overall is the confusing and cryptic level design. While this is a DOOM clone, the levels aren't nearly as spacious or sprawling as DOOM or DOOM II. The design is very, very dense with lots of backtracking and random puzzles. I had to use a guide in about every other level just to get through. While the design is annoying, I still enjoyed the game overall. I completed the base game and Twin Dragon but was turned off by the level design and had no interest in starting up Wanton Destruction (Twin Dragon has really confusing level progression to the point of extreme frustration).   A great remake of the original Shadow Warrior: 7/10.
Great game! Worth buying it.

Wishing I was an eighties kid. I often go back and play classic fps titles such as The Classic Doom, Shadow Warrior Classic, Blood and Duke Nukem 3D. These games don't give me nostalgia but they make me depressed about how the fps genre has taken a turn for the worst.   This Shadow Warrior Classic Redux gives me the chance to be able experience game mechanics that were common 'back in the day'. From the fixed health system, keycard hunting, beautifully made sprites, actually challenging in a fair way (if you die it's your fault), SECRETS (I love having to discover a secret randomly as I just happen to stumble upon it) and the many effective and fun weapons at your disposal (You can carry them all at the same time! Bring this back to the modern day shooters please! XD).   So far this game has been enjoyable for the most part, The level design can sometimes be overwhelming to a newcomer to these types of games (as I was when I was first playing Doom. I had no idea where to go.) but just exploring around making sure you didn't miss a door or a keycard somewhere is not too tedious as you just need to go where there are no corpses of your enemy and then mark that place with the corpses of your enemy to know that you've been there before.   I'd recommend this game to anyone who'd want to experience games as they were way back when. If you don't like this game I guess there's too much wang for you to handle.
